captions.text: Fiquane3 asks
Can you tell us the story how you came to find
and own your new adorable kitten?
For those of you who don't know
We've got a new kitten
Dr.Meemersworth
Dr.Meemersworth
This is Dr.Meemersworth
She's a kitten, she's full of energy
She's like "I'm a kitten"
She is like everywhere
She's coming to my shoulder
she has claws and I'm not wearing a shirt
so...
Hmmm mum!
Why does the kitten have the Spudgy voice?
I think she's going to make a ...
OH GOD OH GOD OH GOD
Can you just grab her?
So four years ago, when we moved to Korea there were
Four years ago~~
She's just like running around and hitting things
So when we moved to Korea four years ago
there wasn't really a big pet culture, right?
Not at all
At the time when we adopted Spudgy,
we rarely saw any dogs in our neighborhood
In fact, people seem very inexperienced with animals
lot of people who saw Spudgy was deathly afraid of him
For those of you who doesn't know Spudgy
He's our little Pekinese dog
and he's like this big
and we spoke in Korea and explain it to people
that he doesn't bite and he's really friendly
but people will actually try to like
scale walls and climb elevators
trying to get away from him
One of our neighbors actually was
when we got in the elevator with Spudgy
she actually physically try to climb up the side of the elevator
OH NO NONONONO
And Spudgy, after a long walk, and was exhausted
and lies flat down on the ground
he's not threat to anyone
I wanna give an impression
I'm gonna be Spudgy,
what Spudgy looks like in the elevator with that woman, ready?
I'm gonna give an impression what that woman looked like with Spudgy
In fact, one time I'd got really annoyed with her
I'd pick up the Spudgy and
"OH~Gi yeob da !!"
which means cute and like
"OH~ BBO BBO HAE~!"
which means you should kiss, and she was like
oh~~ no...
and we waved his little paws to her
and Spudgy was like this the whole time
I'd never saw her again in the elevator afterwards
I think she just decided to take the stairs of the 13th floor from then on
Don't jump!!
You can't make that jump!!
Aham! Where were we?
And even with cats, people are like deathly afraid of them
Our local coffee shop have 2 cats in it
and they are really friendly people cats
all they wanna do is lie in your warm laptop
and have you pat them
People who comes to the shop first time
will like smashed against to the glass door
and when cat jumps up to the table
they are like
they actually physically cowardly go to the corner
and the people in the coffee shop will explain them the cats are ok
and the cats are sitting there like this
That's right be afraid of me, human
I think the point that we are getting here is that
people in Korea aren't comfortable with pets yet
as in are in Western countries like North America or England or Europe
I think that they haven't been exposed to it in households
when they see an animal
think as if it's a wild animal
rather than something like loved, snuggled and dancing in Kpop video
If any of don't you
So speaking of Spudgy we actually got Spudgy in an animal shelter in Korea
We did a video about it long time ago
we're gonna link to it so you can check it out that as well
But don't if you are sensitive because you're gonna cry
I'd cried the first time when I saw the video
and I was in the video
and I cried the third and the fourth time, it was very moving
Dr.Meemersworth in the other hand
we didn't get her from a shelter
But we didn't got her from a pet store
and we didn't get her from a kitty mill
We actually don't support that kind of establishment
so we don't buy any products from there
we don't buy animals from there either
Now we were thinking of originally adopting a cat from an animal shelter
but we've introduced to cats that are fully grown
they handled being around with dogs a little bit worth
Now we didn't get a cat from a shelter
when we tried to introduce Spudgy to older cats
Spudgy was ok
he was like, I'M THE SPUDGY
But cats that were exposed to dogs that weren't grow up with dogs
they were so uncomfortable
We actually took care of our friend's cat for a month when they went back to the States
And she really didn't like hanging out with Spudgy
I don't know why, he's such a chilled dog
But it was pretty funny
because Spudgy will be lying in the room
and she would be like
So we decided to get a kitten instead
for hopes that if the kitten grow up with Spudgy
she would be a lot more comfortable with a dog
now the second problem was that we really wanted to get a Scottish fold kitten
because we heard that they were really relaxed with other animals
they really have a chill attitude
We thought that breed will be the best hanging with Spudgy
They sound like the exact same animal
My animal experience is lazy, what's yours?
LAZY~
We should be best friends
We were really super lucky because
since we didn't wanna buy a Scottishfold from a breeder
we happened to have our Korean friend find online
a super normal Korean family who had a Scottish fold
happened to have kittens
and they are not breeders or sellers or anything
They couldn't have so many cats in their house
so they were getting rid of their kittens
So we were looking for a cat looking like this like a long time
and as soon as our friend said that
"This is the perfect place for you to go"
We've got in a taxi right away
and picked up Dr.Meemersworth instantly
And the home was really great
they raised her really perfectly
We were really sad to see her go
They gave us a little snuggle blanket and some food for her
and she already loves us so much
Snuggles in my head in night time
and she nibbles my ears when I try to sleep
No seriously when you have a cat sleeping in your head the entire night
I actually would have a warm blanket on my head
than my ear gone in the morning
Hey when I wake up, she hugs my entire pillow
Here's like my pillow and here's my head
kitten wants to snuggle
I don't have any real estate in my pillow
Kitten in my pillow
There's a kitten in my pillow,
puppy in my feet
and a giant manthrowky man warrior
And I have this much bed space left
You so fuzzy and cute
You so fuzzy and cute
And that's my cate meowing
Isn't that heart breaking?
Please get me in the video again
That's it for this week's TLDR
and if you have a question for next TLDR
leave your question on the comment section below
Or check out the questions that are already asked
and if you see a question that you like
you can thumb it up
and if we like that question
maybe we'll answer it
And lastly don't forget to subscribe for more TLDRs
where we won't be talking about that much more about our kitten
but will probably ruining our video
I'm a doctor you idiot
DR, Stop speaking in Spudgy's voice

comments.author: Lexi Chapman

comments.text:
I know this is an old video but I wanted to say that breeders are not bad 
when they are raising the kittens and puppies in their home and socializing 
them well with people.  I would never support a puppy/kitten mill or pet 
store which gets their animals from mills.  Most of my animals have come 
from breeders who raise all the animals in their home just as if they were 
their pets.  Always do your research on the breeder.  Ask lots of 
questions.  Don't be afraid to ask to see the parents or see where the 
animals are bred.  A good breeder will be very forth coming about all of 
that.

My next pet I want to check out a shelter first but I specifically want a 
poodle.  Not a poodle mix.  I have owned and trained three poodles in my 
life time and they are wonderful dogs.  Also, since I do all the training 
myself, I like to start with a puppy.  All my cats have always been strays 
or given to the family for free but my last cat was bought from a breeder. 
 I researched for nearly 2 years about bengal cats and finally got one.  I 
had to go to a breeder.  Next bengal (which I hope to not need for many 
many years since my cat now is only 3 and my last two pets, toy poodle and 
domestic cat, lived to be 19) I will check out a bengal rescue first.  But 
again, I train my pets, and bengal cats are super smart.  I got mine when 
he was 13 weeks old and I've trained him.  He can walk on a leash, do many 
tricks such as roll over, and he knows many commands.  Anywho... the 
important thing is to give an animal a forever home.﻿
comments.author: Elizabeth Booth

comments.text:
+Elizabeth Booth glad to know people care about animals in this world.  You 
sound like a real winner, sweet chunks.
comments.author: khricket
Elizabeth Booth

comments.text:
I know many breeders and don't hate them at all, I know they are good 
breeders.   But if you can't understand how it's irresponsible to add more 
dogs to the population, well maybe you should do some research yourself. 
 Where I live anyway, shelters don't put down animals for no reason (maybe 
you are thinking of PETA shelters)  they put animals to sleep because they 
dont have the space or funds to keeps them.  Especially where I live 
because people would rather go to a breeder because they think they'll get 
a better dog, when really there are dogs at the shelter, sometimes from 
great quality breeders, sometimes from people who have died.  Breeders as a 
whole add a shit tonne of dogs to the mix.  While I know puppy mills are 
doing this too, they are doing it out of greed and wouldn't stop until they 
are shut down.  Breeders are more caring and could easily turn their 
operations into a breed specific rescue where people can still get the dog 
breed they want without adding the the population, and also saving those 
breeds of dogs from being killed at shelters.  Many breeders I personally 
know in my area (dog, rabbit, and other rodents... I dont really know any 
other type of breeder personally)  Have stopped for this reason.  They 
understand that there are so many dogs they can be helping and see it as a 
better use for their time to help animals instead of producing more animals 
for really no reason.  Showing at this point, is pretty much a useless past 
time.   It takes many puppies to keep producing perfect specimens which are 
just sold off to other people.  So unless maybe it's a very rare breed, I 
don't see the point.  Do your own research please.  I am very much in tuned 
with every single type of dog breeder, rescue, etc.  I work at a vet office 
and shelter.  In conclusion, what I'm really trying to say is that people 
should do MOST of their research into rescues when looking for a dog.  If 
they REALLY can't find what they want (which really is rare if they did 
enough research) then do a tonne of research finding a good breeder that 
only breeds their animals when they have guaranteed homes for them, and do 
low levels of litters.  They should care about really health alone, 
temperament come close after that and breed standards come after,

Hope this helps.  If you have any other questions, please use google 
because my hands are tired from typing :)

Cheers
comments.author: khricket

comments.text:
Breeders charge less if the puppy or kitten is less than show quality and 
ever see vet ranch on you tube? Shelters euthanize animals for the littlest 
things. I've already said that some breeders are irresponsible. People have 
to do their research, said that too, so you are not supporting someone 
doing the wrong thing. My pets have always been healthy, I had a poodle 
that lived to 19 and was in good shape and only started declining from old 
age at about 17. Point, they all aren't bad if you do your research on the 
breeder first. I don't expect to change your mind either but maybe you 
should meet some breeders before stereotyping all of them.
comments.author: Elizabeth Booth

comments.text:
+Elizabeth Booth What do you think breeders do with puppies and kittens 
that aren't quite right when born? They're culled because they're 
considered useless. And breeds are kept pure by literal inbreeding, which 
causes extensive damage to the animals. German shepherds aren't considered 
perfect unless they've got the slanted, weak back legs in the ring now, 
which is caused from inbreeding and only lowers their quality of life. Pugs 
in the US have been bred over and over so much, that physically and 
mentally, it amounts to about six individual pugs. The reason why certain 
breeds are prone to certain types of health issues is because of breeding. 
Ultimately, breeders want that money, so they're going to leave all the 
pesky facts out. Of course, I don't expect to change your mind.. You're 
obviously steadfast in your support of breeders, but it wouldn't hurt you 
to take a real, honest look at what breeders are actually doing.
comments.author: octoberkittycat

comments.text:
+ZuzuTheUnicorn well according to YOUR logic buying from a breeder (who 
produces more puppies than one would produce babies) is the same as giving 
birth to your own child.  both dogs from breeders and shelters come from 
different mothers so you would not have that maternal bond with any dog. 
 This really wasn't my logic at all as your comparing two entirely 
different things. Also, most countries don't kill the iver excess if 
homeless children while thousands of dogs are killed daily in the USA 
alone.
comments.author: khricket

comments.author: ZuzuTheUnicorn

comments.text:
thats not what I said.  I'm not going to continue this conversation because 
I'm sure you're just as much on a "high horse" as I am and I've really got 
better things to do than continue a conversation that isn't going anywhere. 
 So unless you say anything more enlightening I will not respond :).  I'm 
just saying, if you aren't part of the solution, in this instance you're 
(not you personally, but you as in people adding to the dog population ) 
are part of the problem.  You would feel the same way I do if you worked at 
vets and shelters and had to see dogs die because people are both giving up 
their animals and people think that they need a certain breed to live and 
go to a breeder.  I've worked with many many many dogs and I can say, all 
breeds are pretty much the same (some may have more energy or w/e) really 
mutts and purebreds at shelters and mutts and purebreds from breeders are 
pretty much the same.  If you think otherwise then you have no idea what 
you are missing in the shelter and what life you might save by doing so. 
 Try not to take this so personally, but this is just in general so chill :)

Cheers.
comments.author: khricket

comments.text:
So because I have a preference for a breed I am not a true dog person? 
 There are people, like myself, who love all animals and have a lot of 
empathy for them and the abuses they suffer without any justice being done 
for them.  Just because I mesh best with a certain breed doesn't make me 
any less than you.  Honestly, get off your high horse.
comments.author: Elizabeth Booth

comments.text:
+Elizabeth Booth there are a TONNE of breeders animals that land in 
shelters.  Breeders never really know what's happening to those puppies 
they sell unless theyre stalking the buyers every move, and if they are 
well they wouldnt have enough time for their own dogs.  I wasn't blaming it 
on breeders, but it is slightly irresponsible to be making more animals 
than their country can handle.  And there are MANY breed-specific rescues 
in the US, Canada and probably other countries.  I dont really see people 
as "oh i need this specific dog or i dont want one" really as dog people, 
so maybe you can't really understand as a real "dog person" would since we 
understand that there are homeless dogs out there that are just as good or 
better than puppies straight from the breeder.
comments.author: khricket

comments.text:
If people neutered and spayed their pets, we wouldn't have that problem.  I 
know that problem exists but to blame it on breeders (and I mean strictly 
responsible breeders) is ridiculous.  The people that really contribute to 
that problem are the people that don't fix their pets.  They let them roam 
or worse, they abandon them when the pet becomes more work then they 
thought it'd be.  I am the one choosing to bring a pet into my home and 
family.  They're going to be my responsibility financially and emotionally 
for many many years.  My last dog lived to be 19.  That's a long time to 
have one pet.  I have every right to pick the animal that I like that will 
work best for what I need.  I have no doubt that there are absolutely 
wonderful pets in shelters and I will always consider that option for 
myself for any and all future pets, but I'm not going to be guilted because 
I chose to get a pet from a breeder.  I do my research on the breeds and 
their characteristics.  I do my research on the breeder to make sure they 
are responsible and not running a puppy or kitten mill.  If they meet my 
standards then I absolutely have no qualms about buying a pet from a 
breeder.
comments.author: Elizabeth Booth

comments.text:
+Elizabeth Booth opinion that shelters are over crowded and thousands of 
dogs are killed daily?  Try working at a shelter, its a fact.  Ignorance 
must be bliss.
comments.author: khricket

comments.text: This is just your opinion
comments.author: Elizabeth Booth

having a fear makes you a child, but the way you go about the situation 
does. If you're afraid of something, you don't make a big scene about it 
when it isn't necessary. Like I said I'm terrified of heights and for work 
a lot of the times we have to climb ladders to grab items. I don't start 
crying and throwing a fit at my boss when they ask me if I can grab 
something high. I just remind them that I'm too scared to and them 
understand. You know l, the way an adult should handle an issue.

essentially saying "if you don't want to read this, just take a look at 
this summary). In this case, it's probably saying that there is a long 
version to the topic (ie: the one I'm seeing is Worst Mistake in Korea, so 
it'd be there's a long explanation to it), but instead they are going to 
give the short explanation.

comments.author: Therese Andresen

comments.text:
I understand entirely. People would hate on me a lot just because my dad 
was a breeder (and of pit bulls, at that). I've personally just become 
accustomed to the fact that it really doesn't matter what others think, and 
I have no problem explaining exactly why someone may think like that, but 
also noting of exceptions such as my dad :)
comments.author: Silentgrace11

comments.text:
Yes, I know all this as I am a breeder myself, but it would be nice if 
people just didn't say stuff like all breeders and etc etc. I am not for 
breeding for a specific look or skill, and I have bought a dog with bad 
genes that we had to put down because he was so sick and that breeder 
behind this dog was very  rude towards us when we tried to tell him. BUT 
not all breeders are that way, the majority isn't that way. This makes it 
sound like the majority is bad and always in it just for the money. I am 
not denying there are bad people breeding dogs, but it's just plain dumb to 
assume every breeder is a dick. And that's what some people comment online, 
and frankly I find it very annoying having to read shit all the time, so I 
spoke up about how all breeders are not mean towards their animals.
comments.author: Therese Andresen

comments.text:
I think the main stigma is that they're constantly breeding dogs for 
premium appearance and such, and those who do not make the cut are cast out 
into the streets (my dad happened to be a kind dog breeder who would take 
care of the dogs he couldn't sell, but they are far and few between). That, 
plus the fact that it's also relatively common for breeders to breed two 
dogs that are close in lineage for optimum results. For dogs this doesn't 
result in visual gene alteration like it does in some species, but it can 
often lead to health problems, higher mortality and increased 
agression/mental instability (I usually wasn't allowed to go around dogs 
that my dad bought due to this fact). Finally, it gets a bad rap because 
animal shelters are filled to the brink with animals that end up euthanized 
because people would rather get a dog for the name labelling more than 
anything.

TL;DR: just like with anything else in the world, you have to check all the 
stops before going with a breeder. There's nothing necessarily wrong with 
wanting a dog of a specific breed (especially if you need a hypoallergenic 
dog) but it's best to educate yourself first.
comments.author: Silentgrace11

comments.text:
+Holly Silvester if you want a scottish fold or any other "exotic" type of 
breed always go for trustworthy breeders. Never shop from a pet store. If 
bred badly scottish fold can have a lot of bone trouble. I got mine from a 
trustworthy breeder and he is the most lovable and healthy scott in 
tenerife :)
comments.author: neko chan

comments.text:
Nah, dogs are in heat two times a year, the dogs are pregnant 64 
days(Aprox.) and then after two/three months the puppies are sold. So, dogs 
can have a litter two times a year, but rarely do because the next heat 
comes too soon after the latest litter and the female dog is usually not in 
shape yet to have the puppies then. And even if it works the way you 
describe, why is that wrong? As long as the dogs are happy, it's okay. 
Breeders don't necessarily treat their animals poorly.
comments.author: Therese Andresen

comments.text:
No they aren't, they breed the dogs every 9 months, everytime they have the 
babies they breed them again
